title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: Tidy R client ActiveCampaign API v3. Built httr2 automatic pagination, RDS caching, MCP server support.

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: Request layer (R/request.R) — httr2 request builder auth headers, rate limiting (4 req/sec), retry backoff, response parsing Cache layer (R/cache.R) — RDS file cache TTL, incremental merge (remove old IDs, append new, deduplicate) Entity layer (R/deals.R, R/contacts.R, etc.) — Thin wrappers using ac_paginate(), ac_get_one(), ac_post_one(), ac_put_one(), ac_delete_one()

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: Stored internal environment (exported): - $base_url, $api_key, $timezone, $cache_dir - Set via ac_auth() ac_auth_from_env()

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: Tests don’t require API access: - test-auth.R — Auth state management, error messages - test-request.R — Record parsing, type coercion - test-cache.R — Merge logic, cache store/retrieve - test-utils.R — Phone normalization (NZ/AU) - test-deals.R — Auth requirement check

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: ac_<entity>s() — List (paginated) ac_<entity>(id) — Get one ac_create_<entity>(...) — POST ac_update_<entity>(id, ...) — PUT ac_delete_<entity>(id) — DELETE ac_<entity>_<sub>() — Sub-resources ac_sync_<entity>() — Cached incremental sync

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
code: R/   auth.R              — ac_auth(), credential management   request.R           — httr2 request builder, pagination, parsing   cache.R             — RDS cache with TTL, incremental merge   deals.R             — Deal CRUD   deal-custom-fields.R — Custom field pivot (long → wide)   deal-activities.R   — Activity logs, won date extraction   deal-pipelines.R    — Pipeline/stage metadata   contacts.R          — Contact CRUD   contact-custom-fields.R — Contact custom field pivot   contact-tags.R      — Tag management   accounts.R          — Account CRUD   campaigns.R         — Campaign data   tasks.R             — Task CRUD   users.R             — User listing   automations.R       — Automation listing/triggering   webhooks.R          — Webhook management   tags.R              — Tag management   lists.R             — List management   sync.R              — Incremental sync with cache   mcp.R               — MCP server via mcptools   utils.R             — Phone normalization, URL builders

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: Imports: httr2, tibble, dplyr, tidyr, rlang, cli, janitor, glue, purrr Suggests: mcptools, officer, shiny, future, progressr, testthat, httptest2, withr, config

title: CLAUDE.md - activecampaignr Package
text: Run devtools::test() logic changes Keep IDs character (numeric) avoid integer overflow datetime columns use configured timezone (ac_get_tz()) Response parsing goes ac_parse_records() consistency New entity functions use ac_paginate/ac_get_one/ac_post_one/ac_put_one/ac_delete_one Update NAMESPACE adding exports

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: vignette shows combine ActiveCampaign deal data daily advertising spend calculate: Cost per lead (CPL) — much spend generate one new deal Cost per sale (CPS) — much spend close one deal Lead--sale velocity — many days deal creation won Windowed attribution — week’s ad spend drove week’s sales

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
code: # Fetch deals — cdate/mdate are already POSIXct, value is already numeric deals <- ac_deals()  # Select the columns we need # status is returned as character: "0" = open, "1" = won, "2" = lost deal_dates <- deals |>   transmute(     deal_id = id,     created = as.Date(cdate),     closed = as.Date(mdate),     status = status,     value = value   )  # Won deals with velocity won <- deal_dates |>   filter(status == "1") |>   mutate(     days_to_close = as.integer(closed - created)   )

what: Step 2: Prepare Your Ad Spend Data
title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Create CSV daily advertising spend. file needs two columns: date spend. can export Google Ads, Meta Ads Manager, platform. run multiple channels, either sum one spend column add channel column per-channel analysis.
code: date,spend 2025-01-01,150.00 2025-01-02,200.00 2025-01-03,175.50 ... # Load your spend data spend <- read.csv("daily_spend.csv") |>   mutate(date = as.Date(date))

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
code: # Count new leads (deals created) per day daily_leads <- deal_dates |>   count(date = created, name = "leads")  # Count won deals per day daily_sales <- won |>   count(date = closed, name = "sales")  # Revenue per day daily_revenue <- won |>   group_by(date = closed) |>   summarise(revenue = sum(value / 100, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  # Combine into one daily table daily <- spend |>   full_join(daily_leads, by = "date") |>   full_join(daily_sales, by = "date") |>   full_join(daily_revenue, by = "date") |>   replace_na(list(spend = 0, leads = 0, sales = 0, revenue = 0)) |>   arrange(date)

previous_headings: Step 4: Cost per Lead and Cost per Sale
title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
code: daily_metrics <- daily |>   mutate(     cpl = if_else(leads > 0, spend / leads, NA_real_),     cps = if_else(sales > 0, spend / sales, NA_real_),     roas = if_else(spend > 0, revenue / spend, NA_real_)   )  daily_metrics |>   filter(!is.na(cpl)) |>   summarise(     median_cpl = median(cpl),     median_cps = median(cps, na.rm = TRUE),     median_roas = median(roas, na.rm = TRUE)   )

previous_headings: Step 4: Cost per Lead and Cost per Sale
title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Daily metrics noisy. Weekly aggregation smooths day--week effects small sample sizes.
code: weekly <- daily |>   mutate(week = floor_date(date, "week")) |>   group_by(week) |>   summarise(     spend = sum(spend),     leads = sum(leads),     sales = sum(sales),     revenue = sum(revenue),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   mutate(     cpl = if_else(leads > 0, spend / leads, NA_real_),     cps = if_else(sales > 0, spend / sales, NA_real_),     roas = if_else(spend > 0, revenue / spend, NA_real_)   )  weekly

previous_headings: Step 4: Cost per Lead and Cost per Sale
title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
code: weekly |>   select(week, cpl, cps) |>   pivot_longer(-week, names_to = "metric", values_to = "cost") |>   ggplot(aes(week, cost, colour = metric)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar) +   labs(     title = "Weekly Cost per Lead vs Cost per Sale",     x = NULL, y = "Cost ($)", colour = NULL   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Understanding long takes convert lead sale critical windowed attribution. average velocity 3 weeks, week’s sales driven ad spend 3 weeks ago. Example output (synthetic data):
code: # Velocity distribution velocity_summary <- won |>   summarise(     deals = n(),     median_days = median(days_to_close),     mean_days = round(mean(days_to_close), 1),     p25_days = quantile(days_to_close, 0.25),     p75_days = quantile(days_to_close, 0.75)   )  velocity_summary ggplot(won, aes(days_to_close)) +   geom_histogram(binwidth = 7, fill = "#2c7fb8", colour = "white") +   geom_vline(     xintercept = median(won$days_to_close),     linetype = "dashed", colour = "red"   ) +   labs(     title = "Lead-to-Sale Velocity Distribution",     subtitle = paste("Median:", median(won$days_to_close), "days"),     x = "Days from Created to Won", y = "Deals"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Naive CPS divides week’s spend week’s sales. median velocity 3 weeks, week’s sales actually driven spend 3 weeks ago. matters spend varies time. Consider campaign burst: double ad budget March. Naive CPS spikes March (high spend, number sales closing). Windowed CPS stays flat March spikes 3 weeks later, leads generated burst actually close. gives accurate picture sale really cost. spend steady week--week, two lines overlap lag(spend, 3) ≈ spend. divergence appears spend meaningful variation (campaign bursts, budget changes, seasonal ramps).
code: lag_weeks <- round(median(won$days_to_close) / 7)  windowed <- weekly |>   mutate(     # Shift spend back by the median velocity     lagged_spend = lag(spend, n = lag_weeks),     # Windowed CPS: this week's sales attributed to spend N weeks ago     windowed_cps = if_else(       sales > 0 & !is.na(lagged_spend),       lagged_spend / sales,       NA_real_     ),     windowed_roas = if_else(       !is.na(lagged_spend) & lagged_spend > 0,       revenue / lagged_spend,       NA_real_     )   )

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Example output (synthetic data campaign bursts March September):
code: windowed |>   select(week, naive_cps = cps, windowed_cps) |>   pivot_longer(-week, names_to = "method", values_to = "cost") |>   ggplot(aes(week, cost, colour = method)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar) +   labs(     title = paste0(       "Cost per Sale: Naive vs Windowed (", lag_weeks, "-week lag)"     ),     x = NULL, y = "Cost per Sale ($)", colour = NULL   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: windowed approach aggregate approximation. precise attribution, work deal level: won deal, look ad spend day deal created, divide number leads created day. gives deal attributed acquisition cost. method handles uneven spend naturally. deal created campaign burst gets higher attributed cost one created quiet day, regardless closes.
code: Deal 1042: created 10 Mar, closed 2 Apr (23 days)   Ad spend on 10 Mar: $280   Leads created on 10 Mar: 4   → Attributed cost for deal 1042: $280 / 4 = $70 # For each won deal, look up spend on the day it was created won_attributed <- won |>   left_join(     daily |> select(date, daily_spend = spend, daily_leads = leads),     by = c("created" = "date")   ) |>   mutate(     # This deal's share of that day's spend     attributed_cost = if_else(       daily_leads > 0,       daily_spend / daily_leads,       NA_real_     )   )  # Summary: what did each sale actually cost to acquire? won_attributed |>   filter(!is.na(attributed_cost)) |>   summarise(     deals = n(),     median_cost = median(attributed_cost),     mean_cost = mean(attributed_cost),     p25 = quantile(attributed_cost, 0.25),     p75 = quantile(attributed_cost, 0.75)   )

what: Compare naive vs per-deal CPS over time
title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Example output (synthetic data campaign bursts March September):
code: # Monthly comparison monthly_attributed <- won_attributed |>   mutate(month = floor_date(closed, "month")) |>   group_by(month) |>   summarise(     avg_attributed_cps = mean(attributed_cost, na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   )  monthly_naive <- daily |>   mutate(month = floor_date(date, "month")) |>   group_by(month) |>   summarise(spend = sum(spend), sales = sum(sales), .groups = "drop") |>   mutate(naive_cps = if_else(sales > 0, spend / sales, NA_real_))  monthly_attributed |>   left_join(monthly_naive |> select(month, naive_cps), by = "month") |>   select(month, `Naive CPS` = naive_cps, `Per-Deal CPS` = avg_attributed_cps) |>   pivot_longer(-month, names_to = "method", values_to = "cost") |>   ggplot(aes(month, cost, colour = method)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar) +   labs(     title = "Monthly Cost per Sale: Naive vs Per-Deal Attribution",     subtitle = "Per-deal attributes each sale to spend on the day its lead was created",     x = NULL, y = "Cost per Sale ($)", colour = NULL   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: teams, start per-deal attribution. Fall back windowed don’t reliable deal creation dates.

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Test lag window produces strongest correlation spend sales. helps validate assumed velocity. Example output (synthetic data):
code: # Test lags from 0 to 12 weeks lag_test <- tibble(lag_weeks = 0:12) |>   rowwise() |>   mutate(     correlation = cor(       weekly$spend[1:(nrow(weekly) - lag_weeks)],       weekly$sales[(1 + lag_weeks):nrow(weekly)],       use = "complete.obs"     )   ) |>   ungroup()  best_lag <- lag_test |> slice_max(correlation, n = 1) ggplot(lag_test, aes(lag_weeks, correlation)) +   geom_col(fill = "#2c7fb8") +   geom_col(     data = best_lag,     fill = "#d95f02"   ) +   labs(     title = "Spend-to-Sales Correlation by Lag",     subtitle = paste0(       "Best lag: ", best_lag$lag_weeks,       " weeks (r = ", round(best_lag$correlation, 2), ")"     ),     x = "Lag (weeks)", y = "Correlation"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
code: summary_table <- tibble(   metric = c(     "Total ad spend",     "Total leads generated",     "Total sales closed",     "Total revenue",     "Cost per lead (CPL)",     "Cost per sale (CPS)",     "Return on ad spend (ROAS)",     "Median lead-to-sale velocity",     "Best spend-to-sale lag"   ),   value = c(     scales::dollar(sum(daily$spend)),     format(sum(daily$leads), big.mark = ","),     format(sum(daily$sales), big.mark = ","),     scales::dollar(sum(daily$revenue)),     scales::dollar(sum(daily$spend) / max(sum(daily$leads), 1)),     scales::dollar(sum(daily$spend) / max(sum(daily$sales), 1)),     paste0(round(sum(daily$revenue) / max(sum(daily$spend), 1), 1), "x"),     paste(median(won$days_to_close), "days"),     paste(best_lag$lag_weeks, "weeks")   ) )  summary_table

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: spend CSV includes channel column (e.g., Google, Meta, LinkedIn), group channel throughout:
code: weekly_by_channel <- daily |>   mutate(week = floor_date(date, "week")) |>   group_by(week, channel) |>   summarise(across(c(spend, leads, sales, revenue), sum), .groups = "drop")

title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: Filter deals pipeline analyse specific products:
code: # Only deals from pipeline "1" (e.g., your main sales pipeline) deals <- ac_deals(pipeline = "1")

what: Using deal won dates from activity logs
title: Advertising Effectiveness Analysis
text: AC’s mdate last-modified date, necessarily won date. accurate velocity, use ac_deal_won_dates() extract actual status-change timestamp deal activity logs:
code: won_dates <- ac_deal_won_dates(won$deal_id) won <- won |>   left_join(won_dates, by = c("deal_id" = "deal_id")) |>   mutate(     closed = coalesce(as.Date(won_date), closed),     days_to_close = as.integer(closed - created)   )

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: ActiveCampaign’s API rate limit 5 requests per second. CRM 2,000 deals requires 20 paginated requests just list . analysis script runs multiple times day, ’re iterating report, redundant API calls add fast: cache especially valuable development ’re re-running source("analysis.R") repeatedly.

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
code: Request comes in   │   ├─ Tier 1: CACHE HIT   │   Cache file exists and is younger than TTL?   │   → Return cached data instantly (no API calls)   │   ├─ Tier 2: INCREMENTAL SYNC   │   Cache file exists but is stale?   │   → Fetch only records modified in the last N days   │   → Merge with stored data (replace updated, add new)   │   → Save merged result to cache   │   └─ Tier 3: FULL SYNC       No cache file, or force = TRUE?       → Fetch everything from the API       → Save to cache

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
code: library(activecampaignr) ac_auth_from_env()  # The sync function handles the strategy automatically result <- ac_sync_deals(   lookback_days = 5,           # Tier 2: how far back to check   ttl_minutes = 10,            # Tier 1: cache freshness threshold   force = FALSE,               # Set TRUE to skip straight to Tier 3   include_custom_fields = TRUE # Also cache custom fields )  deals <- result$deals custom_fields <- result$custom_fields

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: performing incremental sync, merge works ID: Record B updated: old version replaced new Record D new: appended Record C unchanged: kept -means incremental sync fetches 2 records instead 1,001, saving ~10 seconds ~19 API calls.
code: Stored:  [A v1, B v1, C v1]   (1,000 records from last full sync) Fetched: [B v2, D v1]         (2 records changed in last 5 days) Result:  [A v1, B v2, C v1, D v1]  (1,001 records)

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: Cache files standard R RDS files stored single directory.
code: # Default location ac_cache_path() # "~/.activecampaignr/cache"  # Change it (e.g., project-local cache) ac_cache_path("~/my-project/.cache")  # Or set at auth time ac_auth_from_env(cache_dir = "~/my-project/.cache")

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: can also read cache files directly needed:
code: ac_cache_status() # # A tibble: 3 x 5 #   key                  rows age_minutes size_kb path #   <chr>               <int>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr> # 1 contacts             2340       15.2    450.1 ~/.activecampaignr/cache/contacts.rds # 2 deal_custom_fields    890        5.3    120.5 ~/.activecampaignr/cache/deal_custom_fields.rds # 3 deals                 890        5.3    280.8 ~/.activecampaignr/cache/deals.rds # Read a cache file manually deals <- readRDS("~/.activecampaignr/cache/deals.rds")

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
code: ac_cache_clear("deals")           # Just deals ac_cache_clear("deal_custom_fields")  # Just custom fields ac_cache_clear("contacts")        # Just contacts

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: Instead clearing re-fetching separately, use force = TRUE:
code: # Equivalent to: clear + full sync in one step result <- ac_sync_deals(force = TRUE)

what: Nuclear option: delete the cache directory
title: Caching and Incremental Sync
Caching and Incremental Sync
text: ActiveCampaign’s updated_after filter returns modified records, tell deleted records. deal deleted AC, incremental sync won’t remove cached data. Fix: Run full sync periodically (e.g., daily):
code: # Weekly full refresh in a scheduled script ac_sync_deals(force = TRUE)

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: TTL based cache file’s last-modified time disk, started R session. another script updates cache file, session pick data next sync call.

what: Custom fields are not incrementally synced
title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: ac_sync_deals(include_custom_fields = TRUE) re-fetches custom field values every non-cache-hit call. AC API support updated_after filtering custom field values, incremental sync possible . large accounts, custom field fetching slowest part. need deal metadata (custom fields), set include_custom_fields = FALSE:

what: Cache is not shared across machines
title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: cache local machine user. run pipeline CI different laptop, starts cold cache. Consider committing seed cache file project repo cold start time matters.

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: cache directory shared default. switch AC accounts, flush cache first: use separate cache directories per account:
code: # Switch accounts safely ac_cache_clear() ac_auth(url = "https://other-account.api-us1.com", api_key = "...") ac_auth(url = "https://account-a.api-us1.com", api_key = "...",         cache_dir = "~/.activecampaignr/cache-a")  ac_auth(url = "https://account-b.api-us1.com", api_key = "...",         cache_dir = "~/.activecampaignr/cache-b")

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: custom caching scenarios, use low-level ac_cache() function:
code: # Cache any expensive computation pipelines <- ac_cache("pipelines", function() {   ac_deal_pipelines() }, ttl_minutes = 60)  # Pipelines rarely change  # Force refresh pipelines <- ac_cache("pipelines", function() {   ac_deal_pipelines() }, force = TRUE)

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
text: production pipelines, sync deals contacts parallel:
code: library(future) plan(multisession, workers = 2)  library(progressr) handlers(global = TRUE)  with_progress({   p <- progressor(steps = 10)    f_deals <- future({     ac_sync_deals(.progress = p)   }, seed = TRUE)    f_contacts <- future({     ac_sync_contacts(.progress = p)   }, seed = TRUE)    deals_result <- value(f_deals)   contacts <- value(f_contacts) })  plan(sequential)

title: Caching and Incremental Sync
code: library(activecampaignr) ac_auth_from_env(cache_dir = "data/cache")  # Daily scheduled script result <- ac_sync_deals(   lookback_days = 7,    # Generous lookback covers weekends   ttl_minutes = 0,      # Always do at least incremental   force = FALSE ) contacts <- ac_sync_contacts(lookback_days = 7, ttl_minutes = 0)  # Weekly: force full refresh to catch deletions if (weekdays(Sys.Date()) == "Monday") {   result <- ac_sync_deals(force = TRUE)   contacts <- ac_sync_contacts(force = TRUE) }  # Analyse deals <- ac_deals_full()

title: Campaign ROI Report with officer
text: Generate branded Word document analysing campaign performance using activecampaignr officer.

title: Campaign ROI Report with officer
code: library(activecampaignr) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(officer) library(flextable)  ac_auth_from_env()

title: Campaign ROI Report with officer
code: campaign_summary <- campaigns |>   select(any_of(c("id", "name", "type", "status", "send_amt",                    "total_amt", "opens", "clicks", "uniqueopens",                    "uniquelinks", "subscriberclicks"))) |>   mutate(across(any_of(c("send_amt", "opens", "clicks", "uniqueopens")),                 as.numeric)) |>   mutate(     open_rate = ifelse(send_amt > 0, uniqueopens / send_amt, NA),     click_rate = ifelse(send_amt > 0, uniquelinks / send_amt, NA)   ) |>   arrange(desc(open_rate))

title: Campaign ROI Report with officer
code: p_open_rate <- campaign_summary |>   filter(!is.na(open_rate), send_amt >= 100) |>   head(15) |>   ggplot(aes(x = reorder(name, open_rate), y = open_rate)) +   geom_col(fill = "#7c3aed") +   geom_text(aes(label = scales::percent(open_rate, accuracy = 0.1)),             hjust = -0.1, size = 3) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent, limits = c(0, 1)) +   labs(title = "Top Campaigns by Open Rate",        subtitle = "Campaigns with 100+ sends",        x = NULL, y = "Unique Open Rate") +   theme_minimal()  p_click_rate <- campaign_summary |>   filter(!is.na(click_rate), send_amt >= 100) |>   head(15) |>   ggplot(aes(x = reorder(name, click_rate), y = click_rate)) +   geom_col(fill = "#0891b2") +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +   labs(title = "Top Campaigns by Click Rate", x = NULL, y = "Click Rate") +   theme_minimal()

title: Campaign ROI Report with officer
code: doc <- read_docx() |>   body_add_par("Campaign Performance Report", style = "heading 1") |>   body_add_par(format(Sys.Date(), "%d %b %Y"), style = "Normal") |>   body_add_par("", style = "Normal") |>    body_add_par("Summary", style = "heading 2") |>   body_add_flextable(     campaign_summary |>       head(10) |>       select(name, send_amt, uniqueopens, open_rate, click_rate) |>       flextable() |>       set_formatter(         open_rate = function(x) ifelse(is.na(x), "-", scales::percent(x, 0.1)),         click_rate = function(x) ifelse(is.na(x), "-", scales::percent(x, 0.1))       ) |>       set_header_labels(         name = "Campaign", send_amt = "Sends",         uniqueopens = "Unique Opens",         open_rate = "Open Rate", click_rate = "Click Rate"       ) |>       autofit()   ) |>    body_add_break() |>   body_add_par("Open Rate Analysis", style = "heading 2") |>   body_add_gg(p_open_rate, width = 6, height = 4) |>    body_add_break() |>   body_add_par("Click Rate Analysis", style = "heading 2") |>   body_add_gg(p_click_rate, width = 6, height = 4)  print(doc, target = "campaign-roi-report.docx")

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
text: need ActiveCampaign API URL API key, found Settings > Developer AC account.
code: library(activecampaignr)  # Option 1: Direct authentication ac_auth(   url = "https://yourname.api-us1.com",   api_key = "your-api-key-here" )  # Option 2: From environment variables (recommended) # Set ACTIVECAMPAIGN_URL and ACTIVECAMPAIGN_API_KEY in .Renviron ac_auth_from_env()

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
text: list functions return tidy tibbles automatic pagination:
code: # All deals deals <- ac_deals() deals  # Won deals only won <- ac_deals(status = 1)  # Deals modified in the last 7 days recent <- ac_deals(updated_after = Sys.Date() - 7)  # Get a single deal deal <- ac_deal("12345")

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
text: Custom fields fetched wide format — one row per deal, one column per field:
code: cf <- ac_deal_custom_fields_wide() cf # # A tibble: 500 x 12 #   deal_id student_id enrolment_id pathway_name ... #   <chr>   <chr>      <chr>        <chr> # 1 1001    S-123      E-456        Full Stack # ...

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
code: # All contacts contacts <- ac_contacts()  # Search by email contact <- ac_contacts(email = "user@example.com")  # Create a contact new_contact <- ac_create_contact(   email = "new@example.com",   first_name = "Jane",   last_name = "Doe",   phone = "021 123 4567" )

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
text: production pipelines, use sync functions cache results RDS files fetch recent changes:
code: # First call: fetches everything, caches to disk result <- ac_sync_deals() deals <- result$deals custom_fields <- result$custom_fields  # Subsequent calls within 10 minutes: returns cache instantly result <- ac_sync_deals()  # <1 second  # Force a full refresh result <- ac_sync_deals(force = TRUE)  # Configure cache TTL result <- ac_sync_deals(ttl_minutes = 30, lookback_days = 3) # Check what's cached ac_cache_status()  # Clear cache ac_cache_clear()

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
code: pipelines <- ac_deal_pipelines() stages <- ac_deal_stages()  # Stages for a specific pipeline stages <- ac_deal_stages(pipeline = "1")

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
code: # Create a deal deal <- ac_create_deal(   title = "New Enrolment - Jane Doe",   value = 500000,  # in cents   currency = "nzd",   pipeline = "1",   stage = "3",   owner = "5",   contact = "12345" )  # Update a deal updated <- ac_update_deal(deal$id, title = "Updated Title", stage = "4")  # Delete a deal ac_delete_deal(deal$id)

title: Getting Started with activecampaignr
text: Caching Sync — Advanced cache configuration Pipeline Analysis — Win rates velocity reports MCP Integration — Use AC AI assistant tool

title: MCP Integration for AI Assistants
text: activecampaignr includes MCP (Model Context Protocol) server exposes ActiveCampaign data tools AI assistants like Claude. uses mcptools package.

title: MCP Integration for AI Assistants
text: Add ~/.claude/claude_desktop_config.json: Make sure ACTIVECAMPAIGN_URL ACTIVECAMPAIGN_API_KEY set environment.

title: MCP Integration for AI Assistants
text: configured, Claude can: Search deals: “Show won deals month” Look contacts: “Find contact email user@example.com” Create deals: “Create new deal Jane Doe, $5000” Check pipelines: “current pipeline stages?” View custom fields: “custom fields deal 12345 ?”

title: MCP Integration for AI Assistants
text: testing, can start server R session: starts stdio-based MCP server listens JSON-RPC messages.

title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
text: vignette shows build PowerPoint pipeline report using activecampaignr, officer, mschart. mschart? embed ggplot PowerPoint via dml(ggobj = ...), chart static image. Recipients can’t edit data, change colours, resize without losing quality. mschart creates native Office charts: fully editable, data table embedded .pptx file. audience can restyle chart PowerPoint without needing R.

title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
text: Use ac_deals_full() get deals pre-joined stage names, pipeline names, owner names:

title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
code: # Won deals with day-of-week and velocity won <- deals |>   filter(status == "1") |>   mutate(     dow = weekdays(mdate),     dow = factor(dow, levels = c(       "Monday", "Tuesday", "Wednesday",       "Thursday", "Friday", "Saturday", "Sunday"     )),     days_in_pipeline = as.numeric(difftime(mdate, cdate, units = "days"))   )

what: Chart 1: Deals Won by Day of Week (mschart bar chart)
title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
code: dow_data <- won |>   count(dow, name = "deals") |>   filter(!is.na(dow))  chart_dow <- ms_barchart(   data = dow_data,   x = "dow",   y = "deals" ) |>   chart_settings(dir = "vertical", grouping = "clustered") |>   chart_labels(     title = "Deals Won by Day of Week",     xlab = NULL,     ylab = "Deals"   ) |>   chart_data_fill(values = rep("#356AE6", 7)) |>   chart_theme(     grid_major_line = fp_border(style = "none"),     legend_position = "n"   )

what: Chart 2: Pipeline Velocity by Stage (mschart bar chart)
title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
code: velocity_data <- won |>   filter(!is.na(stage_title)) |>   group_by(stage = stage_title) |>   summarise(     median_days = round(median(days_in_pipeline, na.rm = TRUE), 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(median_days)  chart_velocity <- ms_barchart(   data = velocity_data,   x = "stage",   y = "median_days" ) |>   chart_settings(dir = "horizontal", grouping = "clustered") |>   chart_labels(     title = "Pipeline Velocity (Median Days by Stage)",     xlab = NULL,     ylab = "Days"   ) |>   chart_data_fill(values = rep("#1A3A7A", nrow(velocity_data))) |>   chart_theme(     grid_major_line = fp_border(style = "none"),     legend_position = "n"   )

what: Chart 3: Win Rate by Owner (mschart bar chart)
title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
code: owner_data <- won |>   filter(!is.na(owner_name)) |>   group_by(owner = owner_name) |>   summarise(     total = n(),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   # Join back to get all deals (not just won) for win rate   left_join(     deals |>       filter(!is.na(owner_name)) |>       count(owner = owner_name, name = "all_deals"),     by = "owner"   ) |>   mutate(win_rate = round(total / all_deals * 100, 1)) |>   filter(all_deals >= 10) |>   arrange(desc(win_rate))  chart_owner <- ms_barchart(   data = owner_data,   x = "owner",   y = "win_rate" ) |>   chart_settings(dir = "horizontal", grouping = "clustered") |>   chart_labels(     title = "Win Rate by Owner (%)",     xlab = NULL,     ylab = "Win Rate (%)"   ) |>   chart_data_fill(values = rep("#16a34a", nrow(owner_data))) |>   chart_theme(     grid_major_line = fp_border(style = "none"),     legend_position = "n"   )

what: Chart 4: Monthly Deal Flow (mschart line chart)
title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
code: monthly_flow <- deals |>   mutate(month = format(cdate, "%Y-%m")) |>   group_by(month) |>   summarise(     created = n(),     won = sum(status == "1", na.rm = TRUE),     lost = sum(status == "2", na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   filter(!is.na(month)) |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(     cols = c(created, won, lost),     names_to = "metric",     values_to = "count"   )  chart_flow <- ms_linechart(   data = monthly_flow,   x = "month",   y = "count",   group = "metric" ) |>   chart_labels(     title = "Monthly Deal Flow",     xlab = NULL,     ylab = "Deals"   ) |>   chart_data_stroke(     values = c(created = "#356AE6", won = "#16a34a", lost = "#dc2626")   ) |>   chart_data_size(values = c(created = 2, won = 2, lost = 2)) |>   chart_theme(legend_position = "b")

title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
text: resulting file standard .pptx opens PowerPoint, Keynote, Google Slides. four charts native Office charts: double-click chart PowerPoint edit underlying data, change colours, adjust formatting.
code: pptx <- read_pptx() |>   # Title slide   add_slide(layout = "Title Slide") |>   ph_with(     "Pipeline Analysis Report",     location = ph_location_type("ctrTitle")   ) |>   ph_with(     format(Sys.Date(), "%d %b %Y"),     location = ph_location_type("subTitle")   ) |>    # Slide 1: Day of week   add_slide(layout = "Title and Content") |>   ph_with(     "Deals Won by Day of Week",     location = ph_location_type("title")   ) |>   ph_with(     chart_dow,     location = ph_location_type("body")   ) |>    # Slide 2: Pipeline velocity   add_slide(layout = "Title and Content") |>   ph_with(     "Pipeline Velocity",     location = ph_location_type("title")   ) |>   ph_with(     chart_velocity,     location = ph_location_type("body")   ) |>    # Slide 3: Win rate by owner   add_slide(layout = "Title and Content") |>   ph_with(     "Win Rate by Owner",     location = ph_location_type("title")   ) |>   ph_with(     chart_owner,     location = ph_location_type("body")   ) |>    # Slide 4: Monthly deal flow   add_slide(layout = "Title and Content") |>   ph_with(     "Monthly Deal Flow",     location = ph_location_type("title")   ) |>   ph_with(     chart_flow,     location = ph_location_type("body")   ) |>    # Slide 5: Summary table   add_slide(layout = "Title and Content") |>   ph_with(     "Summary",     location = ph_location_type("title")   ) |>   ph_with(     data.frame(       Metric = c("Total deals", "Won", "Lost", "Open",                   "Win rate", "Median velocity"),       Value = c(         nrow(deals),         sum(deals$status == "1", na.rm = TRUE),         sum(deals$status == "2", na.rm = TRUE),         sum(deals$status == "0", na.rm = TRUE),         paste0(round(mean(deals$status == "1", na.rm = TRUE) * 100, 1), "%"),         paste(round(median(won$days_in_pipeline, na.rm = TRUE), 0), "days")       )     ),     location = ph_location_type("body")   )  print(pptx, target = "pipeline-report.pptx")

title: Pipeline Analysis with officer
text: can use report. Use mschart want editable charts, dml(ggobj = ...) need ggplot-specific features (facets, custom geoms, annotations):
code: library(ggplot2)  p_custom <- won |>   ggplot(aes(days_in_pipeline)) +   geom_histogram(binwidth = 7, fill = "#356AE6", colour = "white") +   geom_vline(     xintercept = median(won$days_in_pipeline, na.rm = TRUE),     linetype = "dashed", colour = "red"   ) +   annotate(     "text",     x = median(won$days_in_pipeline, na.rm = TRUE) + 5,     y = Inf, vjust = 2, hjust = 0,     label = paste("Median:", round(median(won$days_in_pipeline, na.rm = TRUE)), "days"),     colour = "red"   ) +   labs(title = "Velocity Distribution", x = "Days to Close", y = "Deals") +   theme_minimal()  # Add as a ggplot image slide (not editable, but supports annotations) pptx <- pptx |>   add_slide(layout = "Title and Content") |>   ph_with(     "Velocity Distribution (ggplot)",     location = ph_location_type("title")   ) |>   ph_with(     dml(ggobj = p_custom),     location = ph_location_type("body")   )  print(pptx, target = "pipeline-report.pptx")

title: Interactive Deal Dashboard with Shiny
text: vignette shows build interactive deal explorer using activecampaignr Shiny. runnable example included inst/shiny-examples/deal-dashboard/.

title: Interactive Deal Dashboard with Shiny
code: library(shiny) library(activecampaignr) library(dplyr) library(DT)  # Authenticate before launching ac_auth_from_env()  ui <- fluidPage(   titlePanel("ActiveCampaign Deal Explorer"),    sidebarLayout(     sidebarPanel(       selectInput("status", "Status",                   choices = c("All" = "", "Open" = "0", "Won" = "1", "Lost" = "2")),       dateRangeInput("dates", "Modified Date Range",                      start = Sys.Date() - 90, end = Sys.Date()),       actionButton("refresh", "Refresh Data", class = "btn-primary"),       hr(),       verbatimTextOutput("summary")     ),      mainPanel(       DT::dataTableOutput("deals_table")     )   ) )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   deals_data <- reactiveVal(tibble())    observeEvent(input$refresh, {     withProgress(message = "Fetching deals...", {       result <- ac_sync_deals(force = TRUE)       deals_data(result$deals)     })   }, ignoreNULL = FALSE)    filtered <- reactive({     df <- deals_data()     if (nrow(df) == 0) return(df)      if (nzchar(input$status)) {       df <- filter(df, status == input$status)     }      if (!is.null(input$dates)) {       df <- filter(df,                    as.Date(mdate) >= input$dates[1],                    as.Date(mdate) <= input$dates[2])     }      df   })    output$deals_table <- DT::renderDataTable({     df <- filtered()     if (nrow(df) == 0) return(DT::datatable(tibble(Message = "No deals found")))      display <- df |>       select(any_of(c("id", "title", "value", "status", "owner",                        "cdate", "mdate")))      DT::datatable(display, options = list(pageLength = 25, scrollX = TRUE))   })    output$summary <- renderText({     df <- filtered()     paste0(       "Total: ", nrow(df), " deals\n",       "Total value: $", format(sum(as.numeric(df$value %||% 0), na.rm = TRUE) / 100,                                 big.mark = ","), "\n",       "Date range: ", min(df$mdate, na.rm = TRUE), " to ",       max(df$mdate, na.rm = TRUE)     )   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Chandra P (2026). activecampaignr: Tidy Interface ActiveCampaign API v3. R package version 0.1.0, https://pcstrategyandopsco.github.io/activecampaignr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {activecampaignr: Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3},   author = {Peeyoosh Chandra},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://pcstrategyandopsco.github.io/activecampaignr/}, }

what: Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3
title: Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3
text: tidy, cached, MCP-ready R client ActiveCampaign API v3.

title: Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3
text: activecampaignr gives R users direct analytic access ActiveCampaign CRM. Pull full deal pipeline tibble, join custom fields wide format, feed result straight dplyr, ggplot2, Shiny without writing single API call hand. Built-caching means repeated analysis runs hit disk instead API, incremental sync keeps local data current without re-fetching everything. dataframes correctly typed, number convenience functions included make easier join data perform analysis. Typical use cases: Pipeline analytics — win rates owner, stage, pathway, time period; funnel conversion rates; deal velocity (days per stage) Contact enrichment — merge CRM contacts external data via email phone, NZ/AU phone normalization built Campaign performance — open rates, click rates, revenue attribution across campaigns Custom field analysis — pivot ActiveCampaign’s long-format custom fields one-row-per-deal wide format ready modelling reporting Automated reporting — combine officer PowerPoint/Word reports Shiny interactive dashboards AI-assisted CRM queries — expose pipeline MCP tools AI assistants can answer natural language questions deals contacts

title: Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3
Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3
code: library(activecampaignr)  # Authenticate ac_auth(   url = "https://yourname.api-us1.com",   api_key = "your-api-key" ) # Or: ac_auth_from_env()  # reads ACTIVECAMPAIGN_URL + ACTIVECAMPAIGN_API_KEY  # Fetch deals deals <- ac_deals() won_deals <- ac_deals(status = 1)  # Custom fields in wide format cf <- ac_deal_custom_fields_wide()  # Incremental sync with caching result <- ac_sync_deals() deals <- result$deals

title: Tidy Interface to the ActiveCampaign API v3
text: package builds foundation laid ractivecampaign, pioneered R access ActiveCampaign API. ’m grateful work. proved value R-native AC client informed many patterns used . However, production use scale revealed gaps warranted ground-rebuild:

ActiveCampaign Authentication — ac_auth
text: Set authentication ActiveCampaign API. Stores credentials subsequent API calls. Validates connection test request API.

title: ActiveCampaign Authentication — ac_auth
text: url ActiveCampaign API URL (e.g., "https://yourname.api-us1.com") api_key ActiveCampaign API key timezone Timezone datetime conversion (default: "UTC") cache_dir Directory RDS cache files (default: "~/.activecampaignr/cache")

title: Authenticate from Environment Variables — ac_auth_from_env
text: Reads ACTIVECAMPAIGN_URL ACTIVECAMPAIGN_API_KEY environment. Optionally reads config.yml file.

title: Authenticate from Environment Variables — ac_auth_from_env
text: config_file Path config.yml file (optional). provided config package installed, reads credentials . timezone Timezone datetime conversion (default: "UTC") cache_dir Directory RDS cache files

title: ActiveCampaign Cache Manager — ac_cache
text: RDS-based caching TTL incremental merge support. Returns cached data fresh (within TTL), otherwise calls fn caches result.

title: ActiveCampaign Cache Manager — ac_cache
text: key Cache key (used filename, e.g., "deals") fn function returns tibble (called cache stale) ttl_minutes Time--live minutes (default: 10) force TRUE, bypasses cache

title: Clear the Cache — ac_cache_clear
text: Removes cached RDS files, specific key.

title: Clear the Cache — ac_cache_clear
text: key Optional specific cache key clear. NULL, clears .

ActiveCampaign MCP Server — ac_mcp_server
text: Model Context Protocol server via mcptools AI assistant integration. Creates starts MCP (Model Context Protocol) server exposes ActiveCampaign API functions tools AI assistants like Claude. Requires mcptools package.

title: ActiveCampaign MCP Server — ac_mcp_server
text: server exposes tools: ac_deals — Search list deals ac_deal — Get single deal ID ac_create_deal — Create new deal ac_update_deal — Update deal ac_contacts — Search list contacts ac_contact — Get single contact ID ac_create_contact — Create new contact ac_tags — List tags ac_deal_custom_fields_wide — Get custom fields deals ac_deal_pipelines — List pipelines ac_deal_stages — List stages ac_users — List users ac_automations — List automations

title: ActiveCampaign MCP Server — ac_mcp_server
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Start the MCP server (after authenticating) ac_auth_from_env() ac_mcp_server() } # }

what: Auto-Paginate an ActiveCampaign API Endpoint — ac_paginate
title: Auto-Paginate an ActiveCampaign API Endpoint — ac_paginate
text: Fetches pages paginated endpoint. ActiveCampaign uses offset-based pagination meta.total field.

title: Auto-Paginate an ActiveCampaign API Endpoint — ac_paginate
code: ac_paginate(   endpoint,   entity_key,   query = list(),   limit = 100L,   .progress = NULL )

title: Auto-Paginate an ActiveCampaign API Endpoint — ac_paginate
text: endpoint API endpoint path (e.g., "deals") entity_key key response containing entity list (e.g., "deals", "contacts") query Additional query parameters (filters, sorting, etc.) limit Number records per page (default: 100, AC max) .progress Optional progressr callback (p = NULL none)

title: Auto-Paginate an ActiveCampaign API Endpoint — ac_paginate

ActiveCampaign Request Builder — ac_request
text: Low-level request construction, pagination, rate limiting. Constructs httr2 request object authentication headers, rate limiting, retry logic pre-configured.

title: ActiveCampaign Request Builder — ac_request
code: ac_request(endpoint, method = "GET", body = NULL, query = NULL)

title: ActiveCampaign Request Builder — ac_request
text: endpoint API endpoint path (e.g., "deals", "contacts/123") method HTTP method: "GET", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE" body Request body (list), auto-serialized JSON POST/PUT query Named list query parameters

title: Standardize Phone Number — ac_standardize_phone
text: Normalizes phone number E.164 international format. dialr package installed, supports countries via Google's libphonenumber. Otherwise, falls back built-NZ/AU rules.

title: Standardize Phone Number — ac_standardize_phone
text: phone character vector phone numbers default_region ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code assumed numbers without country prefix (default: "NZ")

title: Standardize Phone Number — ac_standardize_phone
text: character vector E.164 formatted phone strings (e.g., "+6421234567"), NA_character_ unparseable numbers

title: Incremental Contact Sync — ac_sync_contacts
code: ac_sync_contacts(   lookback_days = 5,   ttl_minutes = 10,   force = FALSE,   .progress = NULL )

title: Incremental Contact Sync — ac_sync_contacts
text: lookback_days Days look back incremental sync ttl_minutes Cache TTL minutes force Bypass cache .progress Optional progressr callback

title: Incremental Deal Sync — ac_sync_deals
text: Fetches deals ActiveCampaign intelligent caching: cache fresh (within TTL), returns cached data stored data exists, performs incremental sync (recent changes ) Otherwise, performs full sync

title: Incremental Deal Sync — ac_sync_deals
code: ac_sync_deals(   lookback_days = 5,   ttl_minutes = 10,   force = FALSE,   include_custom_fields = TRUE,   .progress = NULL )

title: Incremental Deal Sync — ac_sync_deals
text: lookback_days Number days look back incremental sync (default: 5) ttl_minutes Cache time--live minutes (default: 10) force TRUE, bypasses cache fetches everything include_custom_fields TRUE, also fetches custom fields wide format (default: TRUE) .progress Optional progressr callback

title: Incremental Deal Sync — ac_sync_deals
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ result <- ac_sync_deals() deals <- result$deals  # Force full refresh result <- ac_sync_deals(force = TRUE) } # }
